conclusion: A basketball is dropped from a height H and rebounds to a height h. Air resistance is proportional to gravitational force.
Air resistance is modeled as constant for simplicity.
The basketball undergoes descent from height H to the ground and ascent from the ground to height h.
The basketball is shown at height H and height h in the image.
Gravity acts downward with force mg.
Air resistance is lambda times the gravitational force, acting opposite to motion.

premise: Gravity and air resistance during descent
conclusion: Net force during descent is mg(1 - lambda).
Acceleration during descent is g(1 - lambda).

premise: Acceleration during descent and initial velocity is 0
conclusion: Velocity just before impact is sqrt(2 * g(1 - lambda) * H).
Pre-collision velocity is v_impact (downward) and post-collision velocity is v_rebound (upward).
Ratio of post-collision to pre-collision velocity is epsilon = v_rebound / v_impact.
During ascent, net force is -mg(1 + lambda).

premise: Acceleration during ascent and final velocity is 0 at height h
v_rebound = epsilon * v_impact and v_impact = sqrt(2g(1 - lambda)H)
v_rebound^2 = 2gh(1 + lambda) and v_rebound = epsilon * sqrt(2g(1 - lambda)H)
